conclusion: Determine the radius d of the light-blocking plate to prevent light from exiting the inner surface.
Critical angle C is the angle of incidence for total internal reflection from a higher to a lower refractive index.
Calculate critical angle C using sin C = 1/n; C = 45 degrees for n = sqrt(2).
Light beam is incident on the outer surface of the hemisphere and refracts into the glass.
Outer radius of hemisphere is R' = sqrt(2)R, inner radius is R.
Apply Snell's Law: sin b = sin a / sqrt(2) for refraction into glass.
For total internal reflection, angle b must be >= critical angle C (45 degrees).
Light-blocking plate must block light that would exit the inner surface.
Radius d of light shield relates to light path projection onto plane perpendicular to axis OO'.
Maximum path for light to be blocked occurs at critical angle C = 45 degrees.
Using tan C = d/R, calculate d = R tan 45 degrees = R.
Radius d of light-blocking plate must be equal to inner radius R to prevent light exit.
